title: Before an Earthquake
description: Preparation is key to staying safe during and after an earthquake.
tips: Create and practice an emergency plan with your family.
Identify safe spots in each room, such as under sturdy furniture or against interior walls.
Secure heavy furniture, mirrors, and appliances to prevent tipping or falling.
Store emergency supplies including water, non-perishable food, flashlight, batteries, and a first aid kit.
Know how to turn off gas, water, and electricity in your home.
Keep important documents (ID, insurance, etc.) in a safe and easily accessible location.
Install emergency alerts on your phone and stay informed about local emergency systems.

title: During an Earthquake (Indoors)
description: Protect yourself by taking immediate action to avoid falling objects and collapsing structures.
tips: Drop to the ground, take cover under sturdy furniture, and hold on until the shaking stops.
Stay away from windows, mirrors, glass, and heavy objects that could fall.
Do not run outside during the shaking.
Stay indoors until the shaking stops and it is safe to exit.
If you're in bed, stay there and protect your head with a pillow.

title: During an Earthquake (Outdoors)
description: Stay in an open area away from potential hazards.
tips: Move to an open space away from buildings, trees, streetlights, and power lines.
Drop to the ground and protect your head and neck.
Remain in place until the shaking stops.
If driving, pull over to a clear location and stop. Avoid overpasses, bridges, and tunnels.

title: After an Earthquake
description: Stay alert and cautious to avoid aftershocks and hazards caused by the quake.
tips: Check yourself and others for injuries and provide first aid if needed.
Be prepared for aftershocks and move to a safe location if your current area is unstable.
Avoid using elevators in damaged buildings.
Inspect your home for damage including gas leaks, electrical issues, and structural hazards.
Do not enter damaged buildings until they are declared safe.
Listen to emergency information and instructions from authorities.
Use text messaging or social media to communicate, as phone lines may be overloaded.
Avoid driving unless it's necessary for safety or emergency purposes.

title: Emergency Kit Essentials
description: Prepare a grab-and-go bag that can support you for at least 72 hours.
tips: Water (at least 1 gallon per person per day)
Non-perishable food
First aid kit
Battery-powered or hand-crank radio
Flashlight and extra batteries
Personal hygiene items (soap, sanitizer, toothbrush)
Whistle (to signal for help)
Cell phone and portable chargers
Important documents (ID, medical records, insurance)
Cash (ATMs may not work)
Extra clothes and blankets
Medications and medical supplies
Mask or face covering
Map of the local area

title: Special Considerations
description: Everyone’s needs are different. Make sure your plan includes special considerations.
tips: Plan for infants, elderly family members, and pets.
Store extra supplies for those with medical conditions or disabilities.
Know your community’s evacuation plans and shelter locations.
Label medications and include emergency contact information with your kit.
Consider cultural and language needs in your communication plan.
